div.p: Greetings. I am returning to you your Rhetica and thank you for it, as does Mr. Steiger, who also read it. In return, I am sending you what I have from the Dauphiné, France, and the Netherlands, most of which is written in the French language, as it was sent here to the lords; for I did not have anyone at hand to interpret it so suddenly; however, you have several there who can understand and interpret it. If I have more, I will send more. That writing of Satan to the king should never have been written or published. It never pleased me; for such writings provoke the wicked more than they edify the good. However, I am not certain about the author of it nor the printer.
Farewell. I am still writing and walking somehow; therefore, you will forgive me if I am brief.
Steiger and all of ours send you many greetings in return, as does Mr. Treasurer Manuel.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger the Elder, the most faithful pastor of the church in Zürich, my honorable lord and dearest compatriot.
